articles.headline: Taking Refuge in Dollar Could Expose World Economy to New Perils
articles.snippet: After the Brexit vote, the American currency is soaring — threatening a fragile recovery in the United States and risking trouble for emerging markets.
articles.abstract: After the Brexit vote, the American currency is soaring — threatening a fragile recovery in the United States and risking trouble for emerging markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is known as the flight to safety, yet it may be leading the global economy toward fresh danger.

articles.headline: U.S. Reveals Death Toll From Airstrikes Outside War Zones
articles.snippet: About 64 to 116 civilians and about 2,500 members of terrorist groups have died in American airstrikes, the Obama administration said, hundreds lower than independent estimates.
articles.abstract: About 64 to 116 civilians and about 2,500 members of terrorist groups have died in American airstrikes, the Obama administration said, hundreds lower than independent estimates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Partially lifting the secrecy that has cloaked one of the United States’ most contentious tactics for fighting terrorists, the Obama administration on Friday said that it believed that airstrikes it has conducted outside conventional war zones like Afghanistan have killed 64 to 116 civilian bystanders and about 2,500 members of terrorist groups.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Private Equity Funds Balk at Disclosure, and Public Risk Grows
articles.snippet: Efforts to require more transparency from private equity firms have hit a wall, even as investors like public pension funds realize diminishing returns.
articles.abstract: Efforts to require more transparency from private equity firms have hit a wall, even as investors like public pension funds realize diminishing returns.
articles.lead_paragraph: It began last year as a promising push by a few states to require private equity firms that invest on behalf of public pension funds and university endowments to be more forthcoming. But the effort has hit a wall as bills in California and Kentucky intended to shed light on fees and practices at these powerful firms have been either killed or watered down.

articles.headline: UnitedHealthcare Sues Dialysis Chain Over Billing
articles.snippet: The suit accuses the chain of pushing patients out of government programs and into UnitedHealthcare plans, which pay more for dialysis treatment.
articles.abstract: The suit accuses the chain of pushing patients out of government programs and into UnitedHealthcare plans, which pay more for dialysis treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private health insurers can pay more than $4,000 for each dialysis treatment. Government health plans like Medicaid pay around $200.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Brand-Name Drug Makers Wary of Letting Generic Rival Join Their Club
articles.snippet: Teva Pharmaceuticals wants to join PhRMA, a powerful trade association, raising alarm among drug companies facing disputes over high prices.
articles.abstract: Teva Pharmaceuticals wants to join PhRMA, a powerful trade association, raising alarm among drug companies facing disputes over high prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, brand-name and generic drug companies have fought each other in Congress, at international trade negotiations and in court. So when the world’s largest generic drug company moved this year to join the powerful trade association for producers of brand-name medicines, pharmaceutical lobbyists were in a swivet.

articles.headline: Joshua Brown, Who Died in Self-Driving Accident, Tested Limits of His Tesla
articles.snippet: Mr. Brown became a victim of an innovation geared toward people like him when his electric sedan collided with a semitrailer, making him the first known fatality in a self-driving car.
articles.abstract: Mr. Brown became a victim of an innovation geared toward people like him when his electric sedan collided with a semitrailer, making him the first known fatality in a self-driving car.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANTON, Ohio — Joshua Brown loved his all-electric Tesla Model S so much he nicknamed it Tessy.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Annalyn Kurtz

articles.headline: A Fatality Forces Tesla to Confront Its Limits
articles.snippet: Elon Musk’s confidence in Tesla’s technology has seemed boundless, but trying to stay ahead of the competition has posed risks.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk’s confidence in Tesla’s technology has seemed boundless, but trying to stay ahead of the competition has posed risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As the co-founder and chief executive of Tesla Motors, the technology billionaire Elon Musk has consistently portrayed his company’s electric cars as cleaner, safer and more innovative than models made by other automakers.

articles.headline: Bangladesh Attack Is New Evidence That ISIS Has Shifted Its Focus Beyond the Mideast
articles.snippet: The Islamic State claimed responsibility after gunmen detonated explosives and killed 20 hostages at a restaurant in Dhaka, the capital.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State claimed responsibility after gunmen detonated explosives and killed 20 hostages at a restaurant in Dhaka, the capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The cook was crouching in a washroom, taking refuge from the gunmen who had invaded the Holey Artisan Bakery, when he understood that there was a logic behind the killing: The people in the restaurant were being sorted.
articles.byline: By Julfikar Ali Manik, Geeta Anand and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Obama After Dark: The Precious Hours Alone
articles.snippet: President Obama has come to consider the solitary hours after dark as essential as his time in the Oval Office. Barely getting five hours of sleep a night, he considers the time alone more important.
articles.abstract: President Obama has come to consider the solitary hours after dark as essential as his time in the Oval Office. Barely getting five hours of sleep a night, he considers the time alone more important.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “Are you up?”

articles.headline: A Wine of One’s Own? They’ll Drink to That
articles.snippet: The owners of a famous Bordeaux chateau let visitors create their own wines — part of a growing trend that marketers call “experiential luxury.”
articles.abstract: The owners of a famous Bordeaux chateau let visitors create their own wines — part of a growing trend that marketers call “experiential luxury.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The French region of Bordeaux is the sacred home of Château Lafite Rothschild and Château Margaux, so it would seem unlikely that wines named Duke of Juice or Bone Ami would come from there.

articles.headline: Inside the Six Weeks Donald Trump Was a Nonstop ‘Birther’
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s foray into the falsehood that President Obama was born outside the United States gave him a base for the primaries and a template for upending political rules.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s foray into the falsehood that President Obama was born outside the United States gave him a base for the primaries and a template for upending political rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph Farah, a 61-year-old author, had long labored on the fringes of political life, publishing a six-part series claiming that soybeans caused homosexuality and fretting that “cultural Marxists” were plotting to destroy the country.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Steve Eder

articles.headline: F.B.I. Interviews Hillary Clinton Over Private Email Server
articles.snippet: The questioning of the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee and former secretary of state lasted about three and a half hours, her campaign said.
articles.abstract: The questioning of the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee and former secretary of state lasted about three and a half hours, her campaign said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. interviewed Hillary Clinton on Saturday morning for its investigation into whether she or her aides broke the law by corresponding through a private email server set up for her use as secretary of state, a controversy that has dogged her presidential campaign and provided fodder for her political rivals.

articles.headline: Pillars of Black Media, Once Vibrant, Now Fighting for Survival
articles.snippet: The influence of black-owned media companies on black culture is diminishing. Companies are smaller and lack the financial resources to compete in the media landscape.
articles.abstract: The influence of black-owned media companies on black culture is diminishing. Companies are smaller and lack the financial resources to compete in the media landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the black community in Chicago and elsewhere, Johnson Publishing Company represented a certain kind of hope.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: ‘President Hillary Clinton?’ She Wants Progress on Immigration and to Drink With G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Advisers and allies say Mrs. Clinton would try to find common ground with Republicans on immigration and infrastructure spending, and appoint women to half of her cabinet posts.
articles.abstract: Advisers and allies say Mrs. Clinton would try to find common ground with Republicans on immigration and infrastructure spending, and appoint women to half of her cabinet posts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should she win the presidency, Hillary Clinton would quickly try to find common ground with Republicans on an immigration overhaul and infrastructure spending, risking the wrath of liberals who would like nothing more than to twist the knife in a wounded opposition party.

articles.headline: Bombing Kills More Than 140 in Baghdad
articles.snippet: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack in a middle-class neighborhood, the deadliest assault in years in the Iraqi capital.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack in a middle-class neighborhood, the deadliest assault in years in the Iraqi capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As celebrations for the Muslim holy month of Ramadan stretched past midnight into Sunday in central Baghdad, where Iraqis had gathered to eat, shop and just be together, a minivan packed with explosives blew up and killed at least 143 people — the third mass slaughter across three countries in less than a week.
articles.byline: By Falih Hassan, Tim Arango and Omar Al-Jawoshy

articles.headline: Fair Play in a Fact-Challenged Political Landscape
articles.snippet: In the rush to gain access to the most talked-about political operatives, cable news stations have been more willing to hire commentators with increasingly partisan agendas.
articles.abstract: In the rush to gain access to the most talked-about political operatives, cable news stations have been more willing to hire commentators with increasingly partisan agendas.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Fourth of July is my favorite holiday. I am from Philadelphia. And I write a column about media.

articles.headline: Why Tech Support Is (Purposely) Unbearable
articles.snippet: Worse, just as you suspected, companies know the torture they are putting you through, with cable and mobile service providers the most egregious offenders.
articles.abstract: Worse, just as you suspected, companies know the torture they are putting you through, with cable and mobile service providers the most egregious offenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: You may consider yourself even-keeled, the kind of person who is unflappable when those around you are losing their cool. But all that goes out the window when you call tech support. Then you fume. Your face turns red. You shout things into the phone that would appall your mother.

articles.headline: Amazon Is Quietly Eliminating List Prices
articles.snippet: As retailers face consumer lawsuits over discounts, Amazon is changing the way it presents bargains to customers.
articles.abstract: As retailers face consumer lawsuits over discounts, Amazon is changing the way it presents bargains to customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a major shift for online commerce, Amazon is quietly changing how it entices people to buy.

articles.headline: Olympics Ease an Ad Blackout, and Brands Flood the Field
articles.snippet: A move to improve relations with athletes by giving their sponsors more leeway may not sit well with companies that pay millions for official status.
articles.abstract: A move to improve relations with athletes by giving their sponsors more leeway may not sit well with companies that pay millions for official status.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some called it a gag rule impinging on freedom of speech. Others bristled at the requirement to abandon longtime sponsors at the very moment they would be entering the international spotlight.

articles.headline: How Anti-Growth Sentiment, Reflected in Zoning Laws, Thwarts Equality
articles.snippet: A growing body of economic literature suggests that efforts in America aimed at things like “maintaining neighborhood character” contribute to segregation and lead to stagnation.
articles.abstract: A growing body of economic literature suggests that efforts in America aimed at things like “maintaining neighborhood character” contribute to segregation and lead to stagnation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — The small city of Boulder, home to the University of Colorado’s flagship campus, has a booming local economy and a pleasantly compact downtown with mountain views. Not surprisingly, a lot of people want to move here.

articles.headline: Drone Strike Statistics Answer Few Questions, and Raise Many
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s release of the civilian death toll from targeted drone attacks revealed an uncertainty about whom it had killed.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s release of the civilian death toll from targeted drone attacks revealed an uncertainty about whom it had killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The promise of the armed drone has always been precision: The United States could kill just the small number of dangerous terrorists it wanted to kill, leaving nearby civilians unharmed.
